sluRm 0.0.9000
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Getting Started with sluRm

    sluRm

    Example

    library(sluRm)
#> On load, `sluRm` sets default options for your jobs (`chdir`, which is the default directory where sluRm will use to create the auxiliar files, and `job-name`, which is the option of the same name in Slurm. You can view/set these at:
#>    ?opts_sluRm
#> or you could just type
#>    "opts_sluRm".

# Suppose that we have 100 vectors of length 50 ~ Unif(0,1)
set.seed(881)
x <- replicate(100, runif(50))

    We can use the function Slurm_lapply to distribute computations

    ans <- Slurm_lapply(x, mean, submit = FALSE)
#> Warning: `X` is not a list. The function will coerce it into one using `as.list`
#> Warning: `submit = FALSE`, which means that the job hasn't been submitted yet. Use sbatch() to submit the job, or you can submit it via command line using the following:
#> sbatch --chdir=/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm --job-name=sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b /home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/01-bash.sh

    Notice the submit = FALSE option. To get more info, we can actually set the verbose mode on

    opts_sluRm$verbose_on()
ans <- Slurm_lapply(x, mean, submit = FALSE)
#> Warning: `X` is not a list. The function will coerce it into one using `as.list`
#> Warning: The path '/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b' already
#> exists and will be overwritten.
#> 
#> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> `opts_sluRm$get_verbose() == TRUE`. The R script that will be used is located at:
#> /home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/00-rscript.r
#> and has the following contents:
#> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> library(sluRm, lib.loc = "/usr/local/lib/R/site-library")
#> .sARRAY_ID         <- as.integer(Slurm_env("SLURM_ARRAY_TASK_ID"))
#> .sINDICES          <- readRDS("/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/INDICES.rds")
#> .sFUN              <- readRDS("/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/FUN.rds")
#> .smc.cores         <- readRDS("/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/mc.cores.rds")
#> .sX                <- readRDS("/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/X.rds")[.sINDICES[[.sARRAY_ID]]]
#> .sseeds            <- readRDS("/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/seeds.rds")
#> set.seed(.sseeds[.sARRAY_ID], kind = NULL, normal.kind = NULL)
#> ans <- parallel::mclapply(
#>     X                = .sX,
#>     FUN              = .sFUN,
#>     mc.cores         = .smc.cores
#> )
#> opts_sluRm$set_chdir("/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm")
#> opts_sluRm$set_job_name("sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b", overwrite = FALSE)
#> saveRDS(ans, sluRm::snames("rds", .sARRAY_ID), compress=TRUE)
#> 
#> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> The bash file that will be used is located at:
#> /home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/01-bash.sh
#> and has the following contents:
#> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> #!/bin/sh
#> #SBATCH --job-name=sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b
#> #SBATCH --output=/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/02-output-%A-%a.out
#> #SBATCH --array=1-2
#> #SBATCH --ntasks=1
#> #SBATCH --cpus-per-task=2
#> export OMP_NUM_THREADS=1
#> /usr/lib/R/bin/Rscript --vanilla /home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/00-rscript.r
#> 
#> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> EOF
#> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#> Warning: `submit = FALSE`, which means that the job hasn't been submitted yet. Use sbatch() to submit the job, or you can submit it via command line using the following:
#> sbatch --chdir=/home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm --job-name=sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b /home/vegayon/Documents/sluRm/sluRm-job-2e8bd17726b/01-bash.sh

    Take a look at the vignette here.

    Installation

    And the development version from GitHub with:

    # install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("USCbiostats/sluRm")

    Example

    This is a basic example which shows you how to solve a common problem:

    In that case, don’t forget to commit and push the resulting figure files, so they display on GitHub!
